description:
'''Regional Mexican music''', also known as '''Música Mexicana''', is an umbrella term encompassing the regional subgenres of [[Music of Mexico#Traditional folk music|Mexico's folk music]] and its derivatives from the [[Southwestern United States]]. It is characterized by its stylistic diversity, with each subgenre representing and originating from a specific region of Mexico. Its roots date back to the 16th–19th centuries, emerging from a fusion of [[Indigenous music of North America|Indigenous]], [[Music of Spain|Spanish]], [[Music of Africa|African]] and other [[Culture of Europe#Music|European]] instruments and musical traditions.

Major subgenres include [[mariachi]], [[Banda music|banda]], [[Norteño (music)|norteño]], [[Corrido|corridos]], [[Tejano music|Tejano]], [[duranguense]], and [[sierreño]]. Mariachi, which originated in [[18th century|18th-century]] [[Jalisco]], achieved international recognition during the [[Golden Age of Mexican Cinema|Golden Age of Mexican cinema]] through figures such as [[Pedro Infante]] and [[Vicente Fernández]]. The 1990s saw the rise of grupero and the so-called "Golden Age of Tejano", led by [[Selena]]. In the 2000s, duranguense gained prominence, while the 2020s were defined by the presence of [[corridos tumbados]], a contemporary fusion incorporating elements of [[Trap music|trap]] and [[hip-hop]], and unprecedented global growth driven by recording artists such as [[Peso Pluma]], [[Natanael Cano]], [[Grupo Frontera]], and [[Carín León]]. 

Within the [[music industry]] of the United States, regional Mexican music became a dominant format on Spanish-language radio, resonating strongly with the [[Mexican Americans|Mexican American population]]. This expansion has been marked by record-breaking [[Music streaming service|streaming]] figures and chart success on platforms such as ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', where the genre has regularly placed songs on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart.
